text.p: An Israeli commander in Lebanon says his country's leading guerrilla enemy there is finding it hard to enlist recruits in the face of the Jewish state's military operations.
Brigadier-General Eli Amitay told Israel's Air Force Journal there were also signs that fighters were defecting from the group, the Shi'ite Moslem "Party of God" known as Hizbollah.
"In the last three months the air force has managed to tilt the balance in the fighting against Hizbollah," Amitay said in the interview made available on Thursday.
"Operations in which warplanes, helicopter gunships and assault helicopters took part caused the Hizbollah organisation to shrink," he said.
Despite the general's assessment, northern Israeli residents said Hizbollah attacks had not seemed to have diminished in recent weeks.
Israeli security officials had been saying that Iran was still actively arming the organisation with shipments of missiles and automatic weapons.
But Amitay said: "Today people are more afraid of joining Hizbollah, and members of the organisation itself are more fearful to act.
"In addition to the fact that Hizbollah finds it hard to find new people to join its ranks, there are signs of a phenomenon of defections," he said.
Israeli troops, backed by South Lebanon Army militiamen, police a 15 km (nine mile) wide security zone in south Lebanon with the aim of preventing attacks on Israel's northern border.
Amitay also said that some months ago a cave was found with 17 shoulder-held rocket launchers for use against planes and helicopters.
